conclusion: Analyze the motion of the particle in both the electric and magnetic fields to determine the radius R of the circular path.
The particle starts from rest at hole a and accelerates through the electric field between plates M and N.
The work done by the electric field is W = qU.
This work is converted into kinetic energy: (1/2)mv^2 = qU.
Solving for v gives v = sqrt((2qU)/m).
Once the particle enters the magnetic field, it experiences a Lorentz force perpendicular to its velocity, causing it to move in a circular path.
The magnetic force is given by F_B = qvB.
The centripetal force required for circular motion is F_c = (mv^2)/R.
Setting the magnetic force equal to the centripetal force gives qvB = (mv^2)/R.
Substitute the velocity v = sqrt((2qU)/m) into the expression for R.
Simplify the expression to get R = (1/B) sqrt((2mU)/q).
The radius R of the circular path of the particle in the magnetic field is R = (1/B) sqrt((2mU)/q).
